author: stoney-the-tiger
body:
After we killed the Iranian terrorist dude, Sulamani, about a year ago I went in big on a number of cloud security stocks including $NET.  I am a software and devops engineer with a lot of exp in the industry and I have seen demos/sales pitches from just about every one of these companies and used many of them (good and bad).  So I bought the stocks that I make good products I enjoy using and trust as a consumer of these products.  Full disclosure, I made these picks because their tech works and I feel that technical leadership in this area will beat out accounting, marketing, and other aspects of successful companies.  That bet has paid off with 300-400% gains in the last year for the companies I bought with every penny of available capital \~yr ago.  Those were $NET, $CRWD, and $ZS I am still long on these.  I also was into $MSFT which is good in this respect and $ESTC (which I unfortunately sold around $100 because they were going sideways). I have since gone into $FROG, $PLTR, and $SUMO which are more recent IPOs.

There are a few categories of attack that you worry about from an IT organizational standpoint.  This list is in no particular order other than the first one because you asked about $NET.

* Distributed Denial of Service (DDOS)
   * Cloudflare ($NET) is the best protection you can have for this.  End of story.  They have many other products that make them a great company. They have introduced a new set of tools that cover everything you need for a work anywhere company.  They also have made some things that do for cloud computing what CDNs (like Akamai) did for static content.  There main competitors are Fastly, Akamai, and Limelight but $NET is best from tech standpoint.
* ID management and access control
   * $MSFT, $OKTA, Ping, Sailpoint from login perspective
   * $FROG is also good from the perspective of managing access control to intellectual property
* Malicious websites and phishing 
   * $ZS, $PANO, Fortinet, and a few others play in this space
* Post attack cleanup
   * $CRWD is the best here
   * $ESTC is actually the best but it is open source and european which I think had some negative influences for me as an investor.   Splunk, $SUMO, Data Dog, and Snowflake can also be really good in this regard 
* Secure development
   * There are a few companies but all of their stuff is hum drum

author: SteveSharpe
body:
Between the two, I think NET has more long-term potential than CRWD.  As a personal rule, I never invest in cybersecurity companies that primarily deliver from the endpoint.  The reason is that, while CRWD is certainly a great play today, endpoint solutions seem to come and go all the time.  It's an easier market to disrupt.

Once a company starts running their critical workloads and applications through the NET infrastructure, I suspect it would be much more difficult to pull away.  NET is more sticky for the customer.

As an alternative, I would offer up PANW or FTNT.  They have more all-encompassing portfolios of security solutions so they can cover more use cases and they can pivot much more quickly.  They also both are very acquisitive, so they are constantly shifting to where the demand is.

author: jon-mcman
body: CRM set to break out. Along with cyber security FTNT. Two great buys

author: m3equals333
body:
FTNT [Fortinet target increased to $190 from $160 at Oppenheimer following checks]

Seems like there are cybersecurity upgrades, guide-ups, and some type of newsflow (SolarWinds etc) like everyday.  👌🔥  

Personally I like pureplay cloud cybersecurity (FTNT has all that obselete physical firewall crap as well).

$CRWD 🚀🚀🚀

author: LuckyChicken29
body:
. Look at the holding rebalance. We now got Enphase, SolarEdge, FirstSolar along with all the cybersecurity plays, Fortinet/Crowdstrike. Bio plays like AstraZeneca.

The meme potential of this ETF just took the fuck off. Even with the old holdings were were still going to hit 35 in Feb but with these we could blow past 40.

author: SteveSharpe
body:
Less growth than NET because they are already bigger and much more established.  But less risk with PANW and FTNT.

Put it this way, NET has a market cap that is up there in size compared to PANW and FTNT, but way less revenue and no earnings.

author: slashrshot
body:
closest I know of is fortinet at 10x.  Which is what im saying. while it is true that the cybersecurity sector is overhyped. 
there is a reason blackberry wouldnt moon, its because its fundamentals does not show it has the potential to.  
you are better off placing your bets on something else that while they have a higher sales multiple, also has higher room to grow.
for example, having a good product(s), having good costumers.  

in the vehicles sector, they are competing with msft and aapl.
in security they are competing vs fortinet and crwd.  if u take a look at their products and offerings, they chances dont look good.

author: bridgeheadone
body:
Caught Palo Alto in the October dip, up 32% or something since.

Very well managed company with growth coming organically and from acquisitions.

Early mover in the SaaS/Cloud security and holds something like 70% of the F100 companies.

Fortinet gets mentioned but I think they kissed the train a bit and are trying to catch up after focusing on small business and individuals.

author: beefstake
body: Look at PANW, ZS, FTNT to start. CRWD was something silly like 63 forward PE when I looked at it last.

author: TroxX
body:
I work in Cybersecurity and BB is completely irrelevant in this Business.  In a "sector" of Cybersecurity it is usually that the top 2-3 companies take like 90% of the marketshare ... Let´s Look at Network Security  the Big players are, Palo Alto Networks, Fortinet and Checkpoint. ...  of those 2 PANW and Fortinet are the only ones actually growing a LOT. 

So back to Blackberry, they made a good Akquisition with Cylance but the solution started lacking behind super fast after they got bought or better said, other companies just went BANANAS....
I´m talking here about Crowd Strike, a really good solution in the EDR field ... next PANW also dips into this market with Cortex XDR,  same with Microsoft, and MANY more ... 
What does this mean for BB Cylance in this field ? Extrem competition that they cant win unless the innovate so extremely fast what I´m not seeing coming. 

If you look at the Charts and Compare BB with PANW ... BB just moves sideways (except to recently... suprise suprise) 
so BB went from 7 to 14 ( just the meme basically)  in the last 5years and PANW from 127 to 350.

If they fail to innovate FAST they will get crushed by the competition.

author: Meymo
body:
This was a fantastic read and mirrors some of my own thoughts regarding the market. I found it interesting that they're also stating that we will have a *"likelihood of low policy rates for the rest of our lives".* Which is the same thing that many commentators on this sub-reddit have also been saying.

For fun, [here's the historical performance](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/backtest-portfolio?s=y&timePeriod=4&startYear=1985&firstMonth=1&endYear=2020&lastMonth=12&calendarAligned=true&includeYTD=false&initialAmount=10000&annualOperation=0&annualAdjustment=0&inflationAdjusted=true&annualPercentage=0.0&frequency=2&rebalanceType=1&absoluteDeviation=5.0&relativeDeviation=25.0&showYield=false&reinvestDividends=true&benchmark=VFINX&portfolioNames=false&portfolioName1=Portfolio+1&portfolioName2=Portfolio+2&portfolioName3=Portfolio+3&symbol1=TDG&allocation1_1=5&symbol2=ADBE&allocation2_1=5&symbol3=ADSK&allocation3_1=5&symbol4=ANSS&allocation4_1=5&symbol5=INTU&allocation5_1=5&symbol6=PAYC&allocation6_1=5&symbol7=VRTX&allocation7_1=5&symbol8=ANET&allocation8_1=5&symbol9=MA&allocation9_1=5&symbol10=PYPL&allocation10_1=5&symbol11=V&allocation11_1=5&symbol12=ABMD&allocation12_1=5&symbol13=ISRG&allocation13_1=5&symbol14=ALGN&allocation14_1=5&symbol15=TTWO&allocation15_1=5&symbol16=ETSY&allocation16_1=5&symbol17=XLNX&allocation17_1=5&symbol18=MNST&allocation18_1=5&symbol19=FTNT&allocation19_1=5&symbol20=NOW&allocation20_1=5) of the "high growth" picks that JPM outlines on page 9 (equally weighted, thereby not optimized towards any specific metric), so we can revisit this in 2022 and see how they did. As a data point, historically, it looks like the running CAGR of this blend is around 40.64%. If someone wants to buy this allocation, they can do so quite simply via fractional shares.

author: TinyTowel
body:
For what? A defunct phone manufacturer who has turned into ANOTHER LINE OF BUSINESS where they compete with Fortinet, Symantec, fucking McAfee and that shit? You think this market segment is going to boom? Your chart is nonsense and compares apples to oranges, you retard.

I realize that you're all just gambling on other peoples' lack of knowledge and you'll likely make a tendy or three. But this graphic is bullshit.
